docs.lead_paragraph: PORTABLE computers that let you give commands or enter text using an electronic pen on the screen could usher in a new era of information sharing. But pen computers like Microsoft's Tablet PC have had only lukewarm success, and writing notes on a palmtop requires learning a kind of shorthand. Pointing at and clicking on on-screen icons using a digital pen can be cumbersome and counterintuitive, and writing on a screen in longhand is much slower than typing. Factor in the huge amount of variation in handwriting and shorthand and it's little wonder computers have had a hard time recognizing them. ''Lots of people have trouble recognizing their own handwriting, so it's not surprising a computer can't do it,'' said Brad Myers, a professor in the human-computer interaction institute at Carnegie Mellon's school of computer science.
docs.abstract: What's Next column on development of pen interfaces for computers; machines use special version of Microsoft Windows and digitizer that samples pen strokes to let users write with digital 'ink,' pick out messages with on-screen keyboard and navigate desktop and folders wtih stylus instead of mouse; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers are devising new (and hopefully better) ways to interact with Tablet PC's and other pen-based computers....

headline.main: Trying to Make the Pen as Mighty as the Keyboard

docs.lead_paragraph: CRITICS have often argued that children who spend too much time playing computer games have trouble staying focused on tasks when they are away from the computer and in the classroom. But a new computer game system is designed to teach children to improve their ability to pay attention. Called the Attention Trainer, the game system uses the principles of neurofeedback, a therapy that involves teaching a user to modify brain waves to achieve a desired result, like stress reduction, relaxation and, in the case of the new game, concentration. It costs $899. Tom Blue, senior vice president and co-founder of East3 Ltd., the company that developed the device, said it ''will teach kids what it feels like to concentrate -- the technology will act as a mirror to accelerate learning.''
docs.abstract: Attention Trainer is a home device that uses games to reward children who focus their attention on tasks at hand; continued usage may lengthen young attention spans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE 14 grade-school students at the workshop in Amagansett had waited patiently, answering questions, viewing slides and never once touching the bins of robot parts placed so temptingly in front of them. Then came the words they longed to hear. ''We're going to give you five minutes without asking us a question,'' their teacher, Josh Brussell, told them.
docs.abstract: Article on Robotech robotics workshop program for children in Amagansett, NY, begun three years ago by former science teacher and toy shop owner Rich Wilson; students, using special kits made by Lego, program robots on computer using icons that represent specific commands; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In Richard Powers's postmodern science fiction ''Galatea 2.2,'' a young novelist, very much like the author, returns from the Netherlands to a Midwestern university, where he teaches a computer called Implementation H, or Helen, the meaning of beauty. By feeding it example after example of the world's great literature and music and engaging it in conversation, researchers hope to imbue the machine with so deep a grasp of human culture that it can pass a comprehensive master's degree examination. Instead it prefers to sing.
docs.abstract: George Johnson essay about ongoing battle with spam email personifies SpamProbe software as his beautiful Helen; explains how program uses Bayesian inference to learn ways to identify unwanted email and recognize legitimate messages; limits of SpamProbe discussed; drawing (M)
